Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Effects of Climate-Induced Changes in Generalist Predators on the Structure and Function of Arctic Food Webs
Award.AbstractNarration:
With forecasted changes in climate, it is necessary to understand how organismal adaptations to climatic drivers fit into a broader ecological context. Changes in artic ecosystems are of particular significance because this region is experiencing the fastest rate of climate change on the planet. Moreover, the soils of the arctic tundra store large amounts of organic matter that could be released as carbon dioxide and methane through decomposition by the microbial community. Faster rates of decomposition in the Arctic could result in positive feedbacks on global climate change. The composition and activity of the microbial communities that are responsible for decomposition are affected by invertebrates in the soil, which are themselves are regulated by predators such as spiders. In other ecosystems, cascading effects of spider predation have been found to indirectly inhibit decomposition. If this also occurs in the Arctic, spiders could provide an important ecosystem service by slowing the release of carbon from tundra soils. This project uses an experimental manipulation of spider density and temperature to examine how the relationship between spiders and their prey affects rates of microbial decomposition in the arctic tundra. Results will provide new insights into the potential feedbacks between global climate change and local changes in community structure and function.

The Co-PI (Amanda Koltz) is dedicated to furthering opportunities in science for students from diverse backgrounds. For this project, she has worked with and trained four undergraduate students, three of which are women, and one of whom is of African American and Native American descent. In Alaska, Koltz has worked with rural and Alaska Native high school students from The Rural Alaska Honors Institute. She will also host a K-12 teacher (PolarTREC Program) in Alaska for the 2012 field season in order to provide the teacher with an opportunity to participate in hands-on field research and help bring arctic science back to the classroom.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Arctic is warming faster than any other biome on the planet, and this makes research on the effects of warming on arctic ecosystem processes especially critical. In particular, warming may increase rates of decomposition in the Arctic, which is concerning, because arctic soils are estimated to store more than twice as much carbon as is in the atmosphere. Thus faster decomposition rates in this region could lead to greater releases of greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide and methane into the atmosphere and potentially accelerate the rate of global climate change.

Because decomposition rates are strongly determined by microbial communities, numerous studies have assessed the effects of climate change in the Arctic by focusing on microbial responses to the warmer temperatures and the greater resource availability that comes from deeper permafrost thaw. However, the extent to which these communities may be affected by other organisms within the soil food web has been largely overlooked. This broader view is important, because we know that the composition and activity of the microbial community can be modified by invertebrates in the soil and that soil invertebrates themselves are regulated by predators such as ground-dwelling spiders. To address this knowledge gap, this research project used a field experiment that manipulated temperature and spider density in the arctic tundra near Toolik Lake, Alaska, to explore the influences of spider predation and warming on the soil food web and on decomposition rates. 

The objectives of this project were to identify the extent to which wolf spider predators influence the structure of the soil food web and whether there were indirect cascading effects of the predators on decomposition rates. We also wanted to identify whether warmer temperatures would strengthen or dampen predator effects on the soil community and decomposition.

We found that wolf spiders do affect densities of soil microarthropods and that the responses of these soil organisms to spiders change under warming. These differences in food web structure under ambient vs. warmer temperatures translated into context-specific indirect effects of predators on decomposition. Specifically, while high densities of wolf spiders lead to faster decomposition rates at ambient temperatures, they are associated with slower decomposition rates in areas that have been experimentally warmed. Our results indicate that warming can dampen effects of predators on soil food webs, with potentially important consequences for the rate at which carbon is lost from arctic soils. These findings improve our understanding of how climate change-induced effects on predators can cascade through food webs, altering critical ecosystem functions, and leading to climate feedbacks with important global implications.

The broader impacts of this project have included mentoring several undergraduate students in the lab and in the field, partnerships with K-12 educators, and comprehensive dissemination of research findings. In particular, the project hosted K-12 science teachers in the field through the PolarTREC Program, which resulted in educational blog posts, webinars, and lesson plans about this project and about polar sciences. Through ongoing collaboration with these educators, the project continues to provide opportunities for individuals that are traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields and who can also act as role models for younger K-12 and university students.
